relation: Holds, protects, and supports internal and external components
Holds blade and magnet; on/off switch
Converts the electrical energy into the horizontal mechanical energy
Reduces speed of rotation and provides more torque; connects to geared wheel
Inner gear - metal; outer gear - plastic
Wires and insulation with a metal connection
title: Table 1: Durabrand Can Opener Bill of Materials
textBeforeTable: The table belows lists the Bill of Materials for the Durabrand Can Opener: Parts number of colors available (#) percentage of customers who like appearance (%) force required to push lever arm (lbs) corrosion value (#) time it takes for blade to dull (yrs) motor lifetime (yrs) time it takes to cut standard lid (sec) volume (in^3) force need to puncture can lid (lbs) maximum thickness of lip on lid (in) allowable can height and width (in) maximum force exerted on magnet without failure (lbs) power consumed (W) Engineering Specifications aesthetically pleasing small force required to push lever arm easy to use non-corrosive blade and geared wheel long lifetime cuts lid quickly small enough to fit on kitchen counter blade cuts through standard can lid fits standard cans magnet holds standard size canned product plug outlet User Requirements This can opener is manufactured by Durabrand. The primary function of the can opener is to open cans by cutting the metal lid off. An electrical motor spins the geared wheel, which in turn spins the can.
textAfterTable: Large Gear and Geared Wheel Module Figure 1: Large Gear and Geared Wheel Module Decisions: type of material gear ratio to reduce angular velocity Critical features: radius gear tooth size life expectancy Expected loading: weight of can Measures to evaluate performance: measure angular velocity force exerted on geared wheel friction between geared wheel and can friction between gear shaft and support structure Medium Gear Figure 2: Medium Gear Module Decisions: type of material gear ratio to reduce angular velocity Critical features: radius tooth size life expectancy Expected loading: force on teeth Measures to evaluate performance: measure angular velocity stress tests friction of gears friction of shaft
